title: Lark Valley Path Walking Route

images.title: Bob Jones / River Lark at Mildenhall
images.caption: River Lark at Mildenhall. Looking downstream towards the centre of the town. On the right are the Jubilee Fields, a public amenity area.

images.title: Bob Jones / River Lark near Mildenhall
images.caption: River Lark near Mildenhall. Looking downstream from the footpath that follows the northern bank of the river.

images.title: Bob Jones / Reflections in the River Lark
images.caption: Reflections in the River Lark.  A peaceful summer's day on the River Lark, east of Barton Mills. This view, looking upstream, is taken from the waymarked Lark Valley Path. This river was once used by barges, as far upstream as Bury St Edmunds.

images.title: Bob Jones / Ivy-covered trees near Icklingham
images.caption: Ivy-covered trees near Icklingham. Looking north along a field boundary from the Lark Valley Path, near Icklingham.

images.title: Bob Jones / River Lark at West Stow Heath
images.caption: River Lark at West Stow Heath. The trail follows the right bank of the river.

images.title: Bob Jones / Fornham Park Lock, River Lark
images.caption: Fornham Park Lock. This disused lock is the fifth of 15 former locks between Bury St Edmunds and Mildenhall.

images.title: Bob Jones / River Lark at Fornham St Genevieve
images.caption: River view at Fornham St Genevieve. The Suffolk golf course extends either side of this narrow river, which was navigable until the early part of the 20th century.

images.title: Bury St Edmunds: looking down the River Lark at the Abbey Gardens by Christopher Hilton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bury St Edmunds, looking down the River Lark at the Abbey Gardens

description: Travel through the River Lark Valley on this interesting and varied walk from Mildenhall to Bury St Edmunds via West Stow Country Park. The easy trail runs for about 13 miles with some fine views of the Suffolk countryside along the way. The path starts at Mildenhall and soon joins the river Lark, following it through the Cavenham Heath Nature Reserve to Icklingham. You continue through the delightful West Stow Country Park with its lakes, wildfowl reserve and interesting reconstructed Anglo saxon village. The park also includes the wildlife rich Lackford Lakes where you can look our for an abundance of water loving birds. The final section continues along the river through Culford to Bury St Edmunds where you finish by the train station. At the end of the walk you can enjoy a stroll through the Bury St Edmunds Abbey Gardens. The river runs through the 14-acre gardens which are built on the site of the former Benedictine Abbey.
